urn:contentItem:5XKC-GBK1-JD1P-T4TY-00000-00Can European banks strike back?2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:55ZLexisNexisCan European banks strike back?Dominic O'Neill

European bank shares have sunk to levels not seen since 2008, and even some of the region's bank CEOs admit it is hard to make a compelling investment case for them. Euromoney speaks to the people at the top about their potential to re-emerge as global leaders.

Illustration: Kevin February IN ADDITION        Bonds aren't the answer for Europe's SMEs, says Mustier

Is there any way out of the gloom infecting Europe's banking sector? 

With the region's economic prospects this year gradually killing hopes for an end to negative rates and a recovery in their interest margins, the European Central Bank's rate cut this September only confirmed the challenges ahead. It will be even harder for European banks to earn their cost of equity. 

In late 2019, the Stoxx600 index of European banks is stuck in almost the same trough it fell in to in the depths of the eurozone crisis. The ECB's new policy of only charging for a relatively small tier of reserves did little to offset the impact of a widely expected rate cut in September. 

The vast majority of European bank stocks are now trading firmly below book value; a clear signal from the market that the sector needs to shrink. Research by financial institution specialist Algebris Investments recently lamented that the cumulative market capitalization of the top 25 European banks has slumped to roughly the same as just one big US bank: JPMorgan. 

In investment banking, the picture is worse. As Kepler Cheuvreux recently noted, the combined market capitalization of four of Europe's biggest investment banking champions "" Barclays, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and UBS "" is less than the smallest of the three big American universal banks, Citi.

Even in their home region, it is an achievement if a European firm is a top-five fee earner in the Dealogic league tables. Over the last five years, US banks' market share in investment banking and trading in Europe has risen nine percentage points to 40%, according to Oliver Wyman. 

At the same time, Europe's share of the global fee pool has declined, while European banks' share in North America has fallen from about a third to a fifth. 

We should have a few pan-European diversified banking models, the JPMorgan, Bank of America, or Citi of Europe   - Frédéric Oudéa, Societe Generale

European bank chief executives have never been so open about their limitations. Jean Pierre Mustier, UniCredit's chief executive and the new president of the European Banking Federation (EBF), notes that investment banking commissions in the US are two or three times higher than in Europe, while retail interchange fees are also twice as high in the US. 

"US banks operate in a much bigger and more profitable market, and on top of that we have negative rates," Mustier tells Euromoney. "European banks are at a competitive disadvantage versus US banks. [European banks'] profitability will probably barely match their cost of capital, as the European market is still fragmented between countries. European banks don't have the scale to reach the profitability of the US, which is a quasi-monopolistic market." 

But is all this pessimism myopic? After all, European banks have not always been less profitable, lower valued and smaller than their US peers. They are also arguably ahead of global rivals in the crucial new area of digital banking and in their success as cross-border retail banks.

Looking through Euromoney's back issues shows that in 1980, half of the world's top 10 banks by assets were European, compared with three today. None of them are in the top five. 

The net income then of two UK banks "" Barclays and NatWest (now part of Royal Bank of Scotland) "" far surpassed that of any US rival. Three of the top five banks by equity were European, including the biggest, Crédit Agricole.

JPMorgan's global investment banking hegemony and group financial outperformance is also relatively new. During most of the early and mid 2000s, return on equity in the high teens and early 20s at France's Societe Generale was way ahead of JPMorgan Chase "" until rogue trader JérÃ´me Kerviel reversed its fortunes in 2007.

In the decades to come, can European banks reclaim a dominant role in global banking?

Societe Generale's chief executive Frédéric Oudéa, Mustier's predecessor at the EBF, describes a vision to Euromoney in which there are more European banks with a balance sheet of around â,¬2 trillion, similar in size to the big US universal banks and compared with around â,¬1.3 trillion at SocGen today. 

"We should have a few pan-European diversified banking models, the JPMorgan, Bank of America, or Citi of Europe "" multi-local banks with a strong foothold and a broader base in retail, with corporate and investment banking, and perhaps asset management," says Oudéa.

Even JPMorgan is humble enough to recognize that the permanency of its dominance is not guaranteed. 

"I would suggest that this whole notion of the retreat of the European banks has been very much overplayed," JPMorgan EMEA chief executive Viswas Raghavan told the audience at Euromoney's Awards for Excellence dinner this year.

The September ECB rate saw the culmination of fears that Europe is heading towards Japanese-style long-term economic stagnation, as aging populations and high debt levels "" now combined with rising economic nationalism "" translate into a large but hobbled banking industry. 

Over the last 20 years, Japan's banking sector lost over a quarter of its net interest income, according to Deutsche Bank research. This caused returns at Japanese banks to halve from high single digits "" what European banks typically earn today "" to low single digits. 

Mainly thanks to French and German clients, eurozone loan growth appears relatively robust today. But the price of credit started to fall in 2019. That's crucial, as net interest income typically makes up about 60% of a bank's revenues. Falling interest rate expectations are already eating into banks' investment yields; even Greek five-year bond yields have fallen below their US equivalents. 

Meanwhile, the consensus among analysts is that tiering alone will not amount to a meaningful offset to ultra-loose monetary conditions and that the ECB is only following the Bank of Japan as it introduces a tiered system. 

"Negative rates are killing the banks," says Alastair Ryan, bank analyst at Bank of America. 

He sees little prospect of positive rates, so he says European banks "" which are built on deposits and deposit income "" could get progressively weaker, especially as income from their rate-hedging portfolios falls. 

To further mitigate the hit, the ECB could embark on fiscal-like responses such as purchasing more private-sector assets, purchasing a higher proportion of peripheral government bonds and perhaps even buying senior unsecured bank debt. 'Fresh air'

As Brexit and the US-China trade war push the German economy towards a recession, calls for a fiscal response are also growing, even in Berlin. 

Due to its size and presence in international wholesale banking, BNP Paribas is a top contender for European champion status. Yet chief executive Jean-Laurent Bonnafé calculates that the eurozone's lag to the US interest rate cycle costs his bank roughly â,¬2 billion in annual profit. 

"Markets and banks are overflowing with liquidity," Bonnafé tells Euromoney. "It's why margins are under pressure in retail, corporate banking, or [the small and medium-sized enterprise sector]." 

BNP Paribas chief executive Jean-Laurent Bonnafé

Nevertheless, Bonnafé says the new ECB executive board taking over on October 31 "" led by former French finance minister and IMF managing director Christine Lagarde "" brings "fresh air" that could boost the health of banks in time, even to the extent that mergers become more of a possibility. 

Davide Serra, founder and chief executive of Algebris Investments, and a long-standing European banking expert, agrees on both points. He says the three or four percentage-point lag of European banks' returns on equity versus US peers is more or less exactly the hit to European banks' net income from the difference in monetary policy rates "" between about $50 billion and $60 billion a year on an aggregate basis. 

"If you were to normalize the rate environment, then European banks are already as profitable as US banks," says Serra. 

This could indicate that European banks are just as well managed as their US peers. 

But even if rates stay negative, Serra says the ECB under Lagarde and vice-president Luis de Guindos (both former politicians) will be "more pragmatic, less academic" on the regulatory front. 

Former governor Mario Draghi's combination of higher capital requirements with negative rates and quantitative easing has been a debilitating remedy for banks. Serra thinks the mandate under Lagarde is tilting towards stimulating growth, not just simply saving the euro and stabilizing the banks.

In contrast to previous communications from the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England, the ECB has not yet been able to declare that the eurozone's banking sector (as opposed to its currency) has stabilized, says BofA's Ryan. Aside from the sector's poor valuations, many banks still look dicey. The ECB's introduction of new deadlines for full provisioning of non-performing loans is one indicator that the accumulation of new burdens has not ended. 

Weak capital structures, such as deferred tax assets, are another concern for the ECB. Deutsche Bank, which has only just embarked on a new, more radical restructuring, remains as a systemic risk. Persistent negative rates hit German banks especially hard.

The Basel committee's move to standardize risk-weighting calculations is a further hit to the structured finance businesses, traditionally important for the European banks. 

The EBA calculated in August that implementation of Basel III in the EU implies an aggregate capital shortfall of â,¬135 billion. The burden can be spread over seven or eight years, but it will still limit what banks can do with their earnings. 

Yet Serra thinks that the ECB could at least change its policy of trapping capital in the banks by constantly asking for more capital under its Targeted Review of Internal Models "" effectively assuming banks must be taking more risk if they increase profits. This restricts dividend pay-out ratios to a much greater extent than is the case in the US under the Fed. 

"It doesn't matter how profitable you are, the regulator claims the profit," says Serra. "That's why they've made the sector uninvestable." 

The problem is not the way European banks are managed, it's Europe   - Ana BotÃ­n, Santander

What's worse, Serra adds, is that below book-share valuations "" partly a reflection of Europe-specific regulatory requirements "" hurts economic growth even more, causing a vicious circle, as banks respond by lending less. The ECB could alleviate this relatively easily by easing capital requirements, Serra argues.

Casper von Koskull, departing chief executive of Nordea, holds a similar kernel of hope for change. He has tried to position Scandinavia's biggest bank to be in a better long-term position for a future wave of pan-European mergers. 

"Weak banks won't determine their own fate if consolidation happens," he told Euromoney earlier this year. "Which company will drive a consolidating business? The one that's valued higher."

But von Koskull thinks the ECB's Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), created in 2014, has kept too tight a leash on what stronger banks can do, unnecessarily holding them back. The supervisor should "allow the strong ones to be stronger," not least by permitting banks with healthy capital and profit to have higher pay-out ratios, which would boost their market capitalization, even if putting a stop on pay-outs by weaker banks is justified.

Von Koskull says supervisors in the US are rightly more liberal in this sense, by allowing banks more of a free rein on what to do with excess capital if they pass the Federal Reserve's stress tests. 

"In Europe, you're holding back the strong banks to wait for the weak ones to catch up," he says.Unions

Beyond the odd regulatory tweak, however, are there any more fundamental reasons for longer-term optimism in Europe's banks? 

Many bank chiefs point to the potential for Europe to forge much deeper banking and capital market unions, spurring bigger and more successful cross-European groups. 

The basic problem, according to many in the industry, is that the top US banks have a much larger share of regional industry profit than their European equivalents, partly thanks to a more rapid and decisive post-2008 restructuring of the sector. 

Over the last three years, the ECB's SSM has been criticized for putting off merger candidates by demanding that any deal must come with a capital raising attached. 

According to von Koskull, banks such as Nordea, which was created from mergers of lenders with large market shares in four Nordic markets around the turn of the century, are proof that cross-border consolidation of big universal banks in Europe can work. 

As an EU institution, the SSM may be naturally inclined to favour cross-border mergers within Europe. Yet the lack of political consensus among individual member states on building complementary common deposit insurance schemes is a big disincentive for banks. 

"We are paying the cost of banking union without the benefits "" 11% of net income to the Single Resolution Fund, on top of all the taxes you can imagine," Oudéa grumbles. 

Crucially, national regulators, even in the eurozone, still make it hard for cross-border banks to move capital within their groups. Unlike the ECB, these national regulators are naturally disposed to dislike it when a group based elsewhere turns a country subsidiary into a mere branch, even if this would greatly benefit the group's efficiency on a European level. 

Executive chairman Ana BotÃ­n

Santander's executive chairman Ana BotÃ­n sums up the challenges when she explains why more banks like hers will not take the plunge and embark on a bolder strategy of pan-eurozone acquisitions. 

"The problem is not the way European banks are managed, it's Europe," she says. "Europe is not an integrated market. If I want to grow in Europe, I can't move money from Germany to the Nordics."

In this sense, European banks are in an even worse position than their equivalents in Japan, which is at least a properly unified banking market. 

According to Serra and others, European policy makers may ultimately have no choice but to strengthen the banking union, as it is a necessary part of monetary transmission. 

"Unless the banking system is healthy, the economy can't be healthy," says Serra.

Societe Generale chief executive Frédéric Oudéa

Oudéa is also unusually optimistic about the imminent prospect of the eurozone coming to an agreement on a common deposit-guarantee scheme. That's partly because he says it has a low political cost relative to other European integration projects and partly because a more internationally assertive China and diplomatic divergence from the US should focus minds on the need for European champions

Oudéa thinks progress on the scheme, and technological enablers, could allow banks to engage in consolidation in anticipation of bigger and better integrated European capital markets. 

"I don't see why a large integrated European market shouldn't look like the US market," he says. "The intellectual construction [of the Capital Markets Union] was to have a market with harmonized rules, deeper capital markets and to mimic a US-style system, which is more balanced between capital markets and banks."

Bonnafé adds that bigger and more integrated capital markets are key, as Europe's banking industry needs more than just higher rates to close the market-cap gap to the big US banks. 

"You need to provide for an additional buffer of profitability," he says, noting that European banks' cost of equity will also rise if ECB rates rise. "The most challenging element "" as it's in the DNA of how banks evolve in continental Europe "" is to have a Capital Markets Union that is relevant and well-managed." 

According to Bonnafé, the situation for European banks would be very different if they were able to sell assets to the capital markets more efficiently, like the big US banks. 

"The reality of Europe is that three quarters of the economy is financed on banks' balance sheets and one quarter on markets, whereas in the US it's the reverse," he says. "You can reduce balance sheet size, free up equity and keep the same market share."

Some of BNP Paribas' businesses are already quite concentrated at a European level, with market shares of between 8% and 10%. Bonnafé points to consumer finance, fixed income, securities services, trade finance and cash management. But he says that's not the case in its domestic retail banks, which are harder to integrate into a single back office because of local differences, especially in regulation.

It took the US 50 years to develop its capital markets. We can imagine in 20 years we can fix it   - Jean-Laurent Bonnafé, BNP Paribas

As things stand, a bank with "a decent market share" on a pan-European scale, "would need an incredible amount of equity and liquidity," says Bonnafé. By contrast, if US banks kept a similar volume of mortgages to the European banks on their balance sheets, "the returns would be dramatically lower." 

Bonnafé notes that BNP Paribas, which is the eurozone's biggest bank by assets, has a market share of about 4.5% across all businesses in the eurozone and a similar size of balance sheet to Bank of America, which has a market share of about 10% in the US. 

If a bank like BNP Paribas were to buy another big bank to increase its eurozone-wide market share, it would therefore need to pay a much higher Financial Stability Board buffer for global systemic risk.

As the UK was the driving force behind the Capital Markets Union, Brexit and the related departure of European Commissioner for financial markets Jonathan Hill, has caused an important hiatus in this project. 

Nevertheless, Bonnafé hopes the EU's capital markets integration efforts will restart under this autumn's new college of European Commissioners. It could take three years to have new CMU regulation to facilitate the production of new assets and, therefore, five years for it to have a big impact on business. 

"It took the US 50 years to develop its capital markets," he says. "We can imagine in 20 years we can fix it."

Widespread acceptance of the necessity of this project is vital and the EU's governance makes it easy for dissenting voices to block such projects. 

"There needs to be a consensus," says Bonnafé. "Some national banking supervisors in continental Europe are reluctant about markets as they are concerned that it's too risky."Challenges

Not everyone is convinced, however, about the near-term prospects of either the banking or markets union projects. The European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) is nowhere near the top of the agenda at the European Commission, having been relegated to the "~too-hard-not-urgent' bucket, says BofA's Ryan. 

Jean Pierre Mustier, UniCredit's chief executive

UniCredit's Mustier is especially sceptical that completion of the banking union, including a pan-European deposit insurance scheme, can be the trigger for a new wave of big cross-border mergers on the continent any time soon "" even if Europe does agree a common backstop to the Single Resolution Fund. 

"The risk profile of European banks is too different today to allow for such a convergence," he says.

Mustier knows the challenges better than most as the German regulator's blocking of capital flows within UniCredit, which owns Germany's third-biggest private bank, is the best-known example of intragroup capital and liquidity controls in Europe. 

In fact, Mustier thinks UniCredit can work well enough without EDIS. The bank is affected by what he sees as a generally misplaced focus by European policymakers up to now. 

"Europe's banking and capital markets union needs to be looked at from the investor not the issuer point of view," he argues. "We need to make sure we have seen from the investor's point of view a true unified and consistent financial sector in Europe, not a sum of domestic markets. 

"What's important for the financial sector in Europe is to have more depth to attract more investment in European banks' equity or bonds." 

European banks have lost the battle in corporate and investment banking   - Jean Pierre Mustier, UniCredit

Mustier still thinks Europe needs bigger banks, especially in Germany and on the corporate side. At the same time, he thinks the sector must recognize its limits. 

"European banks have lost the battle in corporate and investment banking," he says. 

Europe's corporate and investment banks can still compete in the euro market "" mostly in financing, including equity capital markets. But they cannot, as some imagine, post even low single-digit revenue growth. 

"Cash management is the new derivative," is one of Mustier's favourite quips "" typically provocative, and perhaps reflecting his own move to UniCredit as well as the change in European banking.

Even Societe Generale is today, like UniCredit, focusing more on transaction banking rather than solely on the strength in derivatives that drove SocGen's corporate and investment bank when Mustier ran it. 

He says this does not necessarily mean European banks are bad investments, as there is plenty they can do to help themselves. 

Now others, most importantly Crédit Agricole, are following Mustier's decision at UniCredit in the early 2010s to exit cash equities and instead pool resources with Kepler Cheuvreux. 

"When you realize that the game is lost and act to make sure you have critical size, and maintain credibility, it's initially painful, but it's necessary," says Mustier.

Philippe Brassac, chief executive of Crédit Agricole SA, the mutual group's listed arm, admits to Euromoney that there is no chance his group will regain its position as the world's biggest bank. The US's 1994 removal of the Depression-era prohibition on bank acquisitions across state borders and, more recently, the growth of China, have removed such a possibility.

"We have to do miracles with financing the economy," says Brassac. 

He doubts policymakers will be able to fulfil their role of creating the regulatory environment needed for Europe's capital markets to take off. 

"It's more difficult in Europe than in China, Japan or the USA, as Europe is not a country," Brassac continues. "Europe is a place of permanent multilateral negotiation. This is why countries always look at their national banks, so it's impossible to contemplate mergers between different countries." 

What more can European banks do other than accept their limits? 

Huge efforts have not brought most European bank shares above book value. UniCredit has made particularly impressive progress since 2017 in reducing costs and bad debt, and boosting capital, yet it trades at about 40% of its book value. 

"The case for European banks is not easy, compared to US banks," admits Mustier. "Investors want share value that grows, and a dividend yield that is stable to growing, and that's what we intend to deliver. You need to make sure you have stable net earnings "" reliable and credible "" and that you're properly de-risked, so that investors buy into your recurring profitability."

There is, therefore, solace even in Europe's relatively harsh regulatory environment. 

"I welcome the current regulation and I want to have more," Mustier says. (However, he adds that the many global and European regulators should improve their understanding of the combined effect of their various capital demands.)

"Our cost of capital needs to go down," says Mustier. "The market perception is that banks need to be less risky. A higher capital buffer means that you're seen as a safer bank, meaning cost of capital should be lower and this should be positive for the share performance.

"Size is not an answer. It's just about lowering the cost of the product. You need to have a very industrial approach to banking today. The times of very high profitability are behind us. You don't need to spend hours defining the strategy. Do you believe you can make more than your cost of capital? If the answer is no, the strategy is simple: de-risk the bank, optimize the cost base and make sure you have recurring earnings while having a risk profile that will lower your cost of capital."Digitalization

Is all the hand-wringing in European banking about regional fragmentation and lost global wholesale banking share missing the point? 

Some European banks, it could be argued, are already global leaders in retail banking. Given their exposure to emerging markets, some could even offer a more promising growth trajectory than the big US banks.

Digitalization is now probably the single biggest challenge facing the banking industry everywhere. The big tech companies, whose financial services potential banks fear so much, are either American or Chinese. But it is not at all clear that US banks are ahead of European banks on the digital front. In fact, in retail the opposite is true. 

Perhaps this should even be expected, given that the UK, Scandinavia and the Netherlands are ahead of the US in terms of their populations' access to the internet and transitioning to a cashless society. 

Greater wariness about issuing new banking licenses may also have hampered fintech competition and innovation in the US.

"I certainly think we are ahead of the American banks when it comes to a lot of the technology applied in consumer and normal commercial banking," says Ralph Hamers, chief executive of Dutch bank ING. "This is where we feel we are and should continue to be leading. Investment banking doesn't fit us at ING. We've tried it with Barings [the British investment bank ING bought for £1 in 1995]. It just didn't fit our culture."

Spain's BBVA is another reference point for banks around the world with digital aspirations, largely because of its international expansion, including the US. 

"I don't think that the US banks are ahead in the digital race," BBVA's executive chairman, Carlos Torres Vila, tells Euromoney. "We have the best mobile banking app in the world, according to Forrester, for two years in a row. If you look at the performance of our mobile banking app, even in the US, it's the best on many dimensions. We have the highest penetration of digital banking customers in the US, and so on."

Europe's digital banking competitiveness may be both a cause and a result of a greater urgency and ability to find ways to expand abroad.

The core of Hamers' strategy is transforming ING so that its operations are more easily transferrable across borders, so it has greater ability to reap growth and economies of scale, firstly in retail banking. He cites ING's online-only retail businesses in countries such as Germany and Spain, but also outside Europe, as in Australia.

"Where Europeans have to be more inventive than the Americans is in creating cross-border scale, because there are still borders in Europe and there are none in America," he argues. "The Americans don't have that urgency. They have a big chunk of domestic banking revenues in a market with a positive rate environment, where they can have a much more stable income base, on the back of which they can build their more volatile investment banking business."

It's a similar story at BBVA. 

"Retail banking has always been a local business, and even today there's a big element of locality in the solutions we provide our customers, but, in a large part because of digital, the solutions to the problems work everywhere," says Torres Vila. 

"The fundamental problems that people have around money are universal. The solutions have been local until now, because of the legacy of payment systems, the legacy of regulation and habits. 

"As we reinvent the solutions to the same problems "" leveraging technology and data "" the reinvention is universal. It applies to the same problem; it works everywhere. If we have good flow in a mobile banking app for a money transfers, that works everywhere. We don't need to reinvent it."

According to Torres Vila, this means that in countries such as Colombia, Peru and Paraguay, where the competition is mostly local, rival banks' capacity to invest in digital solutions is far more limited. BBVA's banks in those markets, however, can benefit from the combined resources and expertise of its operations in Mexico, Spain, Turkey and the US. 

"We're moving much more to a global organization in terms of how we develop solutions for clients and how we deploy those solutions everywhere else. That's the idea," concludes Torres Vila. "We're not there yet, but we're making big strides towards that globality."Spain

European banks' better internationalization of retail and commercial banking operations has deep roots, especially in Spain. Partly because of links to Latin America, the Spanish are the only banks for which big retail banking share in more than one large economy is unquestionably core to their strategy. Neither BBVA in Mexico nor Santander in Brazil face the kinds of questions that Citi does about its big commercial bank in Mexico.

Other European but not US banks have retail operations straddling medium-sized economies "" notably HSBC, roughly half of whose profit comes from Hong Kong, another colonial legacy.

Alongside BNP Paribas, Santander is often cited as a possible European banking champion, but it is one that "" like BBVA and ING "" is more focused on retail banking. 

By market capitalization, it is the biggest bank in continental Europe, and about a quarter bigger than BNP Paribas, although still about half the market cap of HSBC. Santander only has about 2% of eurozone deposits.

Compared with BNP Paribas, Santander is as much a Latin American as a European bank. The bank carved out a Europe division this year, with the regional country heads now reporting to its former Polish country head, Gerry Byrne, rather than directly to the chief executive.

Santander also has greater ambitions to use technology to bolster its status as the world's leading cross-border retail bank. 

It announced a plan earlier this year to increase investment in IT to the extent that it will be the third-biggest bank in the world in terms of its tech spending. Most of its investment in its mobile phone apps is reusable in other countries, including those in Europe. 

"We believe we can leverage our scale to support more customers across Europe," executive chairman BotÃ­n tells Euromoney.

According to BotÃ­n, however, rather than buying a big bank in Italy or France "" or stepping into the Commerzbank bidding process "" Santander's vehicle for cross-border European expansion today is Openbank, the digital-only Spanish lender it relaunched in 2017 piloting a fully cloud-based IT infrastructure. 

Europe, for Santander, is therefore not the be-all and end-all: which is perhaps the key for any outperforming European bank. 

Although the continent still accounts for about 70% of the bank's loans, Europe fell back to a minority of Santander's profit last year, despite its 2017 purchase of Spain's Banco Popular. 

The impact of Brexit on Santander UK and the tentative recovery of its US business could accentuate that shift.  Bonds aren't the answer for Europe's SMEs, says Mustier

How excited is UniCredit chief executive Jean Pierre Mustier, recently appointed president of the European Banking Federation, about the chances of Europe replicating the US system and replacing businesses' reliance on bank borrowing with bonds? 

Not much, it seems "" despite the European Commission's efforts in this direction.

The tiny volumes of the mini-bond market are less than overwhelming. Of much greater concern in continental Europe and especially Italy is the underdevelopment of venture capital and public equity markets. 

"There's massive underinvestment," he says. "We need more startups in Italy to create jobs; we need to invest more. Who can provide the capital?

"Capital Markets Union 1.0 has not delivered because it was based on the wrong assumption, to cut the borrowers from the lenders. That's not what you need to do in Europe. 

"If you spend some time with a European SME, you understand that they are usually too small to access capital markets by issuing bonds and they do not need long-term bullet funding. 

"They need working capital financing, leasing, and if they need long-term financing, it's amortizing and on very specific terms. The banks are very willing to lend, as in a low-growth environment their clients are not borrowing much. 

"What startups and SMEs need first in Europe is access to equity capital, which is much scarcer than in the US and Asia"¦ We are very happy to lend more, but we lend to companies which have the proper capital structure. Our loans are not a substitute for equity."

Mustier thinks the EU, since Brexit, understands this better now. 

Member states are also, at their own pace, doing more to support venture funding for SMEs. But there have been mistakes "" in particular tax breaks favouring listed equities "" and there are still big constraints, especially the smaller size and lower-risk orientation of the European pension and insurance market compared with the US. 

"There are ways to channel more money into pension funds, which would deal with the deficit of the state; there are ways to allow insurance companies to take more risk," he says.

"Insurance funds in Europe can't take risks because of [the European] Solvency II [Directive]. Pension funds are underdeveloped and investing in double-A or single-A securities. There's no short-term fix, but there's a medium-term solution in terms of making sure that the rules allow pension funds and insurance companies to develop more and take more equity risk. More money from high net-worth individuals also needs to be channelled into risk-taking assets."

urn:contentItem:5S81-J031-F03R-N16M-00000-00Can Facebook and Google's new federal watchdogs regulate tech?2018-05-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:54ZLexisNexisCan Facebook and Google's new federal watchdogs regulate tech?Tony Romm

May 04, 2018( The Today File: http://blogs.seattletimes.com/today/ Delivered by Newstex) Facebook and Google must answer to new cops on the beat - a group of five fresh Washington regulators at the Federal Trade Commission who have the power to punish Silicon Valley if it misbehaves. But veterans of the 103-year old watchdog say that the agency increasingly runs the risk of being outmatched by the very tech giants it oversees without more cash, cutting-edge staff and stronger legal teeth.'For a long time the FTC itself has been pointing out the gaps in its authority,' said Terrell McSweeny, a Democratic commissioner who concluded her three-year tenure last week. 'What I find hopeful about this moment is that people are realizing the consequences of that and having a conversation about it.' On Tuesday, the FTC gained its newest chairman, Joe Simons, and soon he'll be surrounded by a full complement of four other commissioners.

They'll be expected to monitor everything from the fast-growing footprint of companies like Amazon to the security practices of the entire tech industry. Most Read Business Stories Unlimited Digital Access: $1 for 4 weeks[1]Already, they face their first, high-profile test: an investigation into Facebook's recent privacy mishaps. In March, the FTC announced it would probe Facebook's entanglement with Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy that improperly accessed names, 'likes' and other personal information for up to 87 million of the social site's users. If the FTC finds that Facebook erred, it could result in massive fines - penalties that some experts say the agency must levy in order to send an early message that it is able, and willing, to police the country's tech behemoths. 'Will the new FTC have the will to take on today's challenges aggressively?' asked Jessica Rich, the former director of the agency's Bureau of Consumer Protection. 'The FTC really is under-resourced. So if it steps up and takes on the challenges, it still will have a limited amount of resources to do that.' The FTC's purview is vast. It reviews hospital mergers, responds to consumer reports about robocalls and ensures that products labeled as 'made in the USA' are actually manufactured here. It stems from its more than century-old mandate to promote competition and penalize those who engage in unfair or deceptive practices.In recent years, though, the FTC has evolved into the U.S. government's primary regulator of the tech industry. While the country may lack a single, federal online privacy law, the agency still has managed to tap its powers to punish tech giants like Facebook, Google, Twitter and Uber for failing to protect the sensitive information they amass about their users. Despite an ever-expanding workload, the FTC's authorities and resources haven't changed much. Its budget this fiscal year is $306 million - or about a third of one percent of the revenue that Google earned in 2017. Those limited funds help the agency maintain a workforce of about 1,140 - roughly 300 fewer than it had almost four decades earlier, according to FTC records, well before it had to police the internet. 'One of the issues is the ability to hire technologists,' acknowledged Rich, who is now the vice president of consumer policy and mobilization at Consumer Reports. 'The FTC simply can't pay what many technologists make in not even the top echelons of companies.'During an interview before she departed, McSweeny praised the agency for its track record, citing the fact it's achieved a 'terrific return on taxpayer investment.' That includes major settlements with companies like Volkswagen for allegedly defrauding drivers.Still, she stressed the FTC faces major structural challenges - issues that she and her predecessors long have highlighted without much success. The FTC is generally hamstrung in its ability to write new rules, for example, and it isn't always able to fine tech companies on their first privacy or security offense.'It would be helpful to have Congress clarify the FTC's authority around privacy and data security. It would be helpful to have civil penalty authority. I think it would be helpful for the agency to have regulatory authority,' she said. Those strictures now fall to Simons, who officially assumed the title of FTC chairman on Tuesday after serving as an antitrust litigator at the law firm Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton ...rrison for clients like Microsoft and Sony. It's not his first tour of duty in the federal government: Simons worked at the agency as its director of the Bureau of Competition from 2001 to 2003. His office declined to make him available for an interview.He'll be aided by two fellow Republicans: Noah Phillips, a former top aide to Texas Sen. John Cornyn, and Christine Wilson, who was a top executive at Delta. Opposite them will be two new Democratic commissioners: Rohit Chopra, a former regulator at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and Rebecca Slaughter, previously a top advisor to Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer of New York. All but Wilson had been sworn in by this week. To start, the agency is under pressure to penalize not only Facebook but other tech companies that mishandle consumers' data.'The FTC largely failed during the Obama years to address the most pressing challenges,' said Marc Rotenberg, the executive director of the Electronic Privacy Information Center, which brought the complaint that led to the FTC's settlement with Facebook in 2011. 'The evidence of that is made clear every day.'Others would like to see the FTC under its new leaders take a closer look at companies like Amazon, Facebook and Google for potential antitrust concerns. Regulators around the world increasingly are fearful that big tech is too big — especially in Europe, which is still probing Google's business practices. In the United States, the FTC hasn't brought such a major case since its own probe of Google - an investigation it closed in 2013 by leaving the company intact. 'We're in an era in which we have massive consolidation happening throughout virtually every sector of the economy, and we've had over the last two decades the rise of the tech industry,' said Ganesh Sitaraman, co-founder of the Great Democracy Initiative, a new progressive-minded policy nonprofit founded by two former aides to Sen. Elizabeth Warren. 'And in large part the FTC has not been doing its job sufficiently to enforce our antitrust laws.' The organization published research this week that calls for regulating the algorithms that power platforms like Facebook's news feed to ensure they aren't used in ways that may harm rival services. In perhaps a sign of his approach, Simons, the agency's new chairman, told Congress earlier this year that the U.S. government may have been 'too permissive in dealing with mergers and acquisitions.' He said the FTC needed to 'devote substantial resources to determining whether its merger enforcement has been too lax.'Yet the evolving nature of digital challenges could make it hard for the FTC to keep up. McSweeny pointed recently to the rise of online 'disinformation' and 'deepfakes' - videos, in some cases, where politicians are edited to say things they never uttered. Both now register on the radar of a more than century-old agency that's supposed to focus on deception. 'I think this is very important moment,' McSweeny said. 'People not just in America, but around the world, are engaging in a real moment of consideration around how these technologies work.' urn:contentItem:5W2P-M8B1-JC65-531S-00000-00Can fines rein in Big Tech? Privacy regulators spur a debate2019-05-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:55ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON DATELINECan fines rein in Big Tech? Privacy regulators spur a debateBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - As they negotiate a record fine against Facebook, federal privacy regulators sparked a debate in Congress Wednesday over how effective such penalties can be in preventing future abuses by big companies.

Members of a House consumer protection subcommittee also gave a sympathetic hearing to the Federal Trade Commission's request for greater powers and funding to police privacy.

"A large fine in a single case does not solve the problems that consumers face," said Rep. Jan Schakowsky, D-Ill., chairwoman of the Energy and Commerce subcommittee, at a hearing with the five members of the FTC. She said the agency needs more funding and authority "at a minimum to restore consumers' confidence."

Rohit Chopra, one of the FTC commissioners, said that for some big companies, fines alone are a mere "parking ticket."

"We cannot change behavior without finding out who at the top caused those problems," Chopra said.

Although Schakowsky and Chopra didn't specifically mention Facebook, the giant social network was top of mind for lawmakers as the FTC appears close to ending its yearlong investigation of the company's privacy practices and looks to punish Facebook for alleged violations of users' privacy.

The question is whether big fines can be just a cost of doing business for huge companies, failing to deter bad conduct. The fine against Facebook is expected to run as high as $5 billion - stacked against the company's revenue of $55.8 billion last year.

Rep. Michael Burgess, R-Texas, said even a large fine "is inconsequential for a company the size of Facebook."

The FTC is considering a rare action to hold Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg personally accountable for Facebook's alleged failure to honor a 2011 agreement over privacy lapses.

The agency also may limit how Facebook targets advertising to its massive user base - potentially making the action far more than a regulatory slap on the wrist.

Beyond the fine, comprehensive action by the FTC could mark a watershed in federal action against the tech industry in the name of consumer privacy.

By usual practice, the FTC - an independent agency - is split with three Republicans and two Democrats. FTC Chairman Joseph Simons has advocated tougher enforcement action against tech companies and must obtain the agreement of at least two other commissioners for any action on Facebook.

In his testimony, Simons urged the lawmakers to enact privacy and data-security legislation to be enforced by the FTC. The agency has brought more than 65 data security cases and 60 general privacy cases and helped return more than $1.6 billion to consumers in the fiscal year ended in October, Simons noted.

Lawmakers have started work on a new national privacy law that could sharply curtail the ability of the biggest tech companies to collect and make money off people's personal data. The role of the FTC as an enforcer of privacy protections is a key issue in the debate over legislation. Consumer privacy advocates and Democratic lawmakers say the agency currently lacks teeth and have pushed for expanding its powers and funding.

The FTC doesn't have the authority, for example, to levy civil money penalties for first violations for most unfair or deceptive practices. It can only issue orders halting the conduct, as it did with Facebook in 2011.

The agency would be expected to write new privacy rules should Congress pass a new law.

Behind the momentum for a new law is rising concern over a string of scandals and the compromise of private data held by Facebook, Google and other tech giants that have reaped riches by aggregating consumer information. The industry has traditionally been lightly regulated and has resisted closer oversight as a threat to its culture of free-wheeling innovation.

Republicans have generally opposed an expansion of federal authority, but in the wake of the Facebook and other privacy scandals, some have taken a more open view toward the FTC's powers and funding. Some business groups are also proposing an expanded role in privacy protection for the FTC.

The 2011 consent decree with the FTC bound Facebook to a 20-year privacy commitment. Violations could subject the company to fines of $41,484 per violation per user per day. The agreement requires that Facebook users give "affirmative express consent" any time that data they haven't made public is shared with a third party.

The agency started investigating Facebook's privacy practices more than a year ago after reports surfaced that the British political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica had improperly accessed the data of as many as 87 million Facebook users without their consent.

urn:contentItem:5W2P-M9X1-DYN6-W54F-00000-00Can fines rein in Big Tech? Privacy regulators spur a debate2019-05-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:55ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONALCan fines rein in Big Tech? Privacy regulators spur a debateBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - As they negotiate a record fine against Facebook, federal privacy regulators sparked a debate in Congress Wednesday over how effective such penalties can be in preventing future abuses by big companies.

Members of a House consumer protection subcommittee also gave a sympathetic hearing to the Federal Trade Commission's request for greater powers and funding to police privacy.

"A large fine in a single case does not solve the problems that consumers face," said Rep. Jan Schakowsky, D-Ill., chairwoman of the Energy and Commerce subcommittee, at a hearing with the five members of the FTC. She said the agency needs more funding and authority "at a minimum to restore consumers' confidence."

Rohit Chopra, one of the FTC commissioners, said that for some big companies, fines alone are a mere "parking ticket."

"We cannot change behavior without finding out who at the top caused those problems," Chopra said.

Although Schakowsky and Chopra didn't specifically mention Facebook, the giant social network was top of mind for lawmakers as the FTC appears close to ending its yearlong investigation of the company's privacy practices and looks to punish Facebook for alleged violations of users' privacy.

The question is whether big fines can be just a cost of doing business for huge companies, failing to deter bad conduct. The fine against Facebook is expected to run as high as $5 billion - stacked against the company's revenue of $55.8 billion last year.

Rep. Michael Burgess, R-Texas, said even a large fine "is inconsequential for a company the size of Facebook."

The FTC is considering a rare action to hold Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg personally accountable for Facebook's alleged failure to honor a 2011 agreement over privacy lapses.

The agency also may limit how Facebook targets advertising to its massive user base - potentially making the action far more than a regulatory slap on the wrist.

Beyond the fine, comprehensive action by the FTC could mark a watershed in federal action against the tech industry in the name of consumer privacy.

By usual practice, the FTC - an independent agency - is split with three Republicans and two Democrats. FTC Chairman Joseph Simons has advocated tougher enforcement action against tech companies and must obtain the agreement of at least two other commissioners for any action on Facebook.

In his testimony, Simons urged the lawmakers to enact privacy and data-security legislation to be enforced by the FTC. The agency has brought more than 65 data security cases and 60 general privacy cases and helped return more than $1.6 billion to consumers in the fiscal year ended in October, Simons noted.

Lawmakers have started work on a new national privacy law that could sharply curtail the ability of the biggest tech companies to collect and make money off people's personal data. The role of the FTC as an enforcer of privacy protections is a key issue in the debate over legislation. Consumer privacy advocates and Democratic lawmakers say the agency currently lacks teeth and have pushed for expanding its powers and funding.

The FTC doesn't have the authority, for example, to levy civil money penalties for first violations for most unfair or deceptive practices. It can only issue orders halting the conduct, as it did with Facebook in 2011.

The agency would be expected to write new privacy rules should Congress pass a new law.

Behind the momentum for a new law is rising concern over a string of scandals and the compromise of private data held by Facebook, Google and other tech giants that have reaped riches by aggregating consumer information. The industry has traditionally been lightly regulated and has resisted closer oversight as a threat to its culture of free-wheeling innovation.

Republicans have generally opposed an expansion of federal authority, but in the wake of the Facebook and other privacy scandals, some have taken a more open view toward the FTC's powers and funding. Some business groups are also proposing an expanded role in privacy protection for the FTC.

The 2011 consent decree with the FTC bound Facebook to a 20-year privacy commitment. Violations could subject the company to fines of $41,484 per violation per user per day. The agreement requires that Facebook users give "affirmative express consent" any time that data they haven't made public is shared with a third party.

The agency started investigating Facebook's privacy practices more than a year ago after reports surfaced that the British political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica had improperly accessed the data of as many as 87 million Facebook users without their consent.

The agreement requires that Facebook users give"affirmative express consent" any moment that data they have not made people is shared with a third party.The bureau began investigating the privacy practices of Facebook after reports surfaced that the British consulting firm Cambridge Analytica had accessed the information as many as 87 million Facebook users with their permission.

urn:contentItem:5XNK-M771-JC3V-61YC-00000-00Can Genius Really Win Its Lawsuit Against Google?2019-12-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:55ZLexisNexisCan Genius Really Win Its Lawsuit Against Google?

In 1991, the Supreme Court fielded a case about two warring phonebook companies in northwest Kansas. Rural Telephone Service Company Inc. refused to license its local information to Feist Publications Inc., so Feist went ahead and copied part of Rural's phonebook. Rural shrewdly placed false entries in its directory, caught Feist in the act, and sued for copyright infringement. But despite Rural's ingenuity, the Supreme Court ruled that the raw data collected in phonebooks were not copyrightable.

Phonebooks are long gone in 2019, but a similar situation arose this week: The site Genius, known for crowd-sourcing lyrics and annotations from listeners and occasionally artists, filed a lawsuit against Google, alleging that the search engine and its partner company LyricFind lifted verses and choruses wholesale from Genius without attribution or compensation. Much like Rural Telephone Service Company Inc., Genius came up with a neat ruse to help make its case: First, an apostrophe pattern concealed in song lyrics that spelled out "red handed" in Morse code (which is even older than phonebooks), then a spacing pattern that spelled out "genius."

While the scenario is familiar, the legalese is different this time around.

Genius "alleges that by taking the content created on their site and misappropriating it and using it for commercial purposes, [Google and LyricFind are] violating the terms of use on their website," explains Imraan Farukhi, an entertainment lawyer and an assistant professor at Syracuse University's S.I. Newhouse School. On top of that, Genius' suit accuses Google and LyricFind of "unethical and unfair anti-competitive practices," which Farukhi says "can give rise to actionable legal claims" in New York. Genius demands at least $50 million from Google and LyricFind in compensation.

A representative for Genius declined to comment on the lawsuit, while a representative for Google referred Rolling Stone to a conciliatory, months-old company blog post. In an email, Darryl Ballantyne, founder and CEO of LyricFind, tells Rolling Stone that "we have not had any contact with Genius since June, and in fact, have not even been served with the complaint."

"From what we're reading online," Ballantyne added, "[the suit] is completely frivolous and without merit." (Genius did not respond to a request for comment on Ballantyne's statement.)

But Don Gorder, an attorney and the chair of the music business and management department at Berklee College of Music, says Genius' watermarking trap "is pretty clever." "It looks like they do have a pretty strong case against LyricFind for lifting those lyrics and then, when putting those out through Google, violating their terms of service agreement," Gorder continues. "Does that add up to $50 million [in damages]? That's probably a stretch."

Genius' suit is a strange one - it's about copying, but not about copyright. That's because Genius and Google both license song lyrics from their owners (either publishing companies or songwriters) but then create the transcripts on their own. "It's an odd industry practice that companies that are in the business of displaying lyrics are not actually getting the source material from the licensors," Farukhi says. "They're just transcribing those themselves."

What's more, Genius became a successful company thanks in large part to the unpaid work of tens of thousands of music fans who transcribe and annotate without any compensation. In what seems like a hypocritical turn, Genius is now accusing Google and LyricFind of doing a version of the same thing - benefitting from someone else's work without paying for it. Not only that, Genius was forced to settle with the National Music Publishers Association in 2014 after the NMPA accused the site of using song lyrics without permission. No one would say that Genius is the perfect David to take a shot at Google's Goliath.

"It looks like [Genius has] a pretty strong case against LyricFind for lifting those lyrics and then, when putting those out through Google, violating their terms of service agreement," says one lawyer

But Genius' suit could still be cutting, because it comes at a time when distrust of Google and other massive technology conglomerates is at an all-time high. In March, the European Union levied a third billion-dollar-plus fine on Google in three years; each penalized the company for anti-competitive practices.

The U.S. lags behind the E.U. in terms of regulating pretty much everything, but the political climate for big tech companies is no kinder stateside. Sen. Elizabeth Warren has made "break up big tech" a central tenet of her presidential campaign. And in a surprising moment of bipartisan agreement, even the Justice Department has opened an antitrust review of tech conglomerates, acknowledging that "without the discipline of meaningful market-based competition, digital platforms may act in ways that are not responsive to consumer demands."

One man cheering Genius' suit is Brian Warner, founder and CEO of the site CelebrityNetWorth, who has publicly accused Google of stealing his company's work to debilitating effect. "When I was looking at Twitter yesterday, the first question was, 'Why does Genius have the right to this?'" Warner says. "We need to all get over that. The bigger thing here is, Google cannot just look at what people are going to search for and scrape their own version to choke traffic off."

Genius' lawsuit accuses Google of cribbing lyrics as far back as 2016. When a curious listener searches for lyrics in Google, the first result to appear is a read-out from a partner like LyricFind. This not only pushes the link to Genius' website further down in the search results - especially when users are on their phones - it renders the lyrics site mostly superfluous.

The suit filed by Genius claims it approached the search engine about the alleged plagiarism but was mostly ignored. So Genius took matters into its own hands, creating watermarks to help bolster its own investigation into Google's behavior. "This is an interesting case because Genius had done so much due diligence in trying to confirm that LyricFind was providing Google improperly with content listed from Genius' page," Farukhi says.

This summer, Genius went public with its accusations in The Wall Street Journal, claiming that the apostrophe watermark had popped up numerous times in Google search read-outs. The search engine made a public display of concern, but Genius' suit claims no substantive action was taken. The site accuses Google of offering "platitudes of 'high standards' and 'best practices'" while "continu[ing] to exploit content misappropriated from Genius' website."

That exploitation allegedly wreaks havoc on Genius' traffic. The company claims that when Selena Gomez released her new single "Lose You to Love Me" in October, 75 percent of the users who searched for the track's lyrics were initially clicking through to Genius' website. But then Google allegedly swiped Genius' lyrics - the company says it detected its watermark in the search engine's display box - and the click-through rate nosedived to five percent.

The suit "is pretty dramatic in showing how Google can drive the traffic to a website down," says David Lowery, a prominent critic of big tech and lead singer of the groups Camper Van Beethoven and Cracker. (In the past, Lowery has been both a critic and a supporter of Genius.) "It illustrates how [Google] can act as a monopoly in certain cases - using their dominant search position and content scraping to maintain their status as the market leader by eating up other people."

 "This is not a good look for Google when they're getting re-examined for antitrust stuff" - David Lowery

Genius is far from the first company to accuse Google of this sort of anti-competitive behavior. Yelp, which also relies on user-generated content, has been in a years-long battle with the search engine; Yelp's chief executive, Jeremy Stoppelman, took his case to Congress. So did Warner, who told the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Antitrust that Google's decision to lift information from CelebrityNetWorth without consent devastated the site's traffic, leaving Warner's creation "treading water with cement blocks around our feet."

In his testimony, Warner also described Google as "an $800 billion company that employs an army of lawyers, lobbyists, think tanks, and talking heads." That's part of why the tech company has continued to skate by despite repeated allegations of anti-competitiveness. Will Genius' suit be any different?

"There are some questions as to the unilateral enforceability of a website's terms of use," Farukhi acknowledges. "But generally courts have said that terms of use are enforceable just like any other contract. Sometimes it depends on certain aspects of how reasonable it is that the users will know these terms exist and find them." And while multiple lawyers contacted by Rolling Stone find it unlikely this lawsuit will ever reach trial, if it ever did, Genius' use of watermarks "lend[s] itself to being persuasive evidence" of alleged theft.

Who would be held responsible for that theft? Genius is leveling separate claims against both Google and LyricFind. But "Google is saying, 'It's not us, we get our lyrics from LyricFind,'" Gorder explains. "I'm wondering if something will come forward where Google goes against LyricFind because they have some sort of indemnity agreement with them."

Google also works with another third-party lyric provider, Musixmatch, which was not named in the lawsuit. Max Ciociola, CEO and founder of Musixmatch, says the company also takes a user-driven approach to lyric generation, much like Genius or Wikipedia. In contrast, "LyricFind is not a company known for having a community," Ciociola says. "So they can't really scale - we're talking about 40,000 new tracks per day coming out. If you don't have a community like Musixmatch or Genius, how can you add the content? There is only one way: scraping."

In the end, the optics of Genius' suit might be more valuable than the actual court case, since the company's action continues to ratchet up public pressure on Google. "This is not a good look for Google when they're getting re-examined for antitrust stuff," Lowery says. "It's not like the FTC would start an investigation because of this, but if they are gonna look into this stuff again, or if the Europeans are looking into this stuff again, it's a really clear example of how Google can abuse its dominant search position."

"Google is under fire for a lot of things," Gorder concludes. "Genius is basically saying, 'Hey! Us too.'"

urn:contentItem:5X5W-P4K1-JCMN-Y4GH-00000-00Can Germany's social market economy system cope with another 70 years?2019-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:55ZLexisNexisCan Germany's social market economy system cope with another 70 years?

Oct 02, 2019( Deutsche Welle Business: http://www.dw.com/en/top-stories/s-9097 Delivered by Newstex) Germany's prosperity has often been pinned on its form of business responsibility known as the "social market economy." It moved with the times and withstood German unification, but can it hold up to today's challenges?The German economy is the third-strongest in the world and Germany is an export giant. Unemployment is low.

Compared with their American counterparts, German employees work on average 400 hours less a year, enjoy long holiday breaks and a strong safety net. What accounts for all this good luck? Many point to the country's "social market economy" system, the soziale Marktwirtschaft.The term was first coined by the German economist Alfred Müller-Armack in 1947 after the end of World War II. It was a time when the Allied military command rationed food and goods, enforced price and wage regulations, and cigarettes were a real substitute for currency.Soon Ludwig Erhard started to use the phrase to describe his ideas for Germany's post-war economy. And though at the end of the war, Erhard was nearly 50 and had never held any political office what he said mattered, because he became economy minister of West Germany in1949. It was a position he held until 1963.Getting West Germany working again after the war was more important than simply making products or money. Getting people into jobs brought about social peace at a difficult time, and if the country was successful it could fend off communism.Other countries like France, Italy and Austria also experienced a boom, but nothing like Germany, and these years have broadly come to be described as a time of miracles. Erhard for his part has been nicknamed the "father of the German economic miracle" and often called the "incarnation of prosperity" or simply the "miracle man."Erhard's sense of fairness"The outstanding economic development of Germany after the Second World War has been significantly influenced by the social market economy," Jörg Rocholl, president of the European School of Management and Technology (ESMT) in Berlin, told DW. "Its biggest merit is the balance between work and capital in enabling competition. On the one hand, it gives companies the greatest possible freedom. It uses social elements to ensure that those who cannot successfully participate in the economy are socially secure."In the past 70 years the workings of Germany's social market economy have widened and now encompass more than Erhard imagined. His ideas were something between the extremes of ultraliberal laissez-faire economics and a Marxist socialist — in other words a planned — system. Performance-based competition was the key to it all.Basically he wanted a minimally regulated free market economy without day-to-day government interference where supply and demand determined prices, wages and what was produced. He called for private property rights, tough antitrust laws and codetermination, a system that puts worker representatives on company boards in the hope of reaching a consensus on wages, benefits and working conditions.Perhaps what Erhard wouldn't recognize today is the country's welfare system. He loved entrepreneurship and always put the "market" before the "social" in his social market economy and was not in favor of excessive social benefits. He wanted people to work hard and stand on their own as much as possible. Today's current health care, pension and unemployment systems go beyond his ideals. A new world orderJörg Rocholl from ESMT notes that the principles of the social market economy are slowly being softened. He criticizes the government for increasingly intervening in pricing and market mechanisms. A perfect example of this is the current discussion around putting a temporary hold on housing rent hikes in Germany. Not only that, but authorities want to set price limits in the future to cushion rising rents."Any artificial slowing down of the price mechanism like we saw in East Germany leads to a decline in investment and the building infrastructure suffers. In the end, nobody benefits," said Rocholl. Especially this year when Germans are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and the subsequent unification of East and West Germany, many people in the former East feel that they have been left behind. It's not hard to imagine how surprised people in East Germany felt when a new economic and social system was imposed on them in 1989. After all, they had lived in a planned socialist system for many decades and have struggled to catch up.The situation in Eastern Germany is not due to the fact that a market economy is bad, but rather that the East German system was economically finished even before 1989," explained Rocholl, referring to secret internal government reports. "Even before the fall of the Berlin Wall in October 1989, Gerhard Schürer, head of the Central Planning Commission of East Germany, had submitted a secret report on the economic situation of the county to the politburo," according to Rocholl. "The report showed the catastrophic state of the production facilities because of worn-out equipment and an enormous need for repairs. In addition, it showed that the country was already so heavily indebted abroad that a state bankruptcy was imminent."Looking forwardDespite the challenges of integrating East and West in the past three decades, as a whole the unified Germany has roared ahead economically. Today many countries look at its current success to see what parts they can take from it.Erhard called for "prosperity for all" and indeed Germany is riding high at the moment despite a slight recent downturn. When things go well, people don't ask questions. From 2005 to 2019, unemployment dropped from 10% to 5%. But the moment things turn sour, the tides will turn on whatever system is in place.A recent report on Germany's social market economy published by KfW, the country's state owned development bank, point out problems facing the county like growing income disparity, poverty, climate change, a stumbling global trade regime, demographic change and dismal progress in digitalization.This is a long list. Additionally, many businesses say they need more flexibility, especially when it comes to hiring and firing workers. No one system can be everything to everyone, yet it seems like the social market economy is being attached on all sides. Should the economy tank as some are predicting, the cries for it to be dismantled will only grow.Germany must rise to these enormous challenges. The KfW report hit the nail on the head when it stated "securing prosperity is a permanent task." The government will be called on to bring about more social peace and solutions to some big problems. "In his book 'Prosperity for All,' Erhard wrote that as economy minister, he was not the representative of large commercial enterprises and cartels, but someone who had to promote the well-being of everyone by ensuring competition. Exactly this point is more important today than ever. How do we deal with big, powerful companies like the big tech giants? What kind of competition regulation do we need?" concluded ESMT's Rocholl.To stay on top in a changing world, Germany may need to come up with a new "economic miracle" plan.

Unemployment is low.

Compared with their American counterparts, German employees work on average 400 hours less a year, enjoy long holiday breaks and a strong safety net. What accounts for all this good luck? Many point to the country's "social market economy" system, the soziale Marktwirtschaft.The term was first coined by the German economist Alfred Müller-Armack in 1947 after the end of World War II. It was a time when the Allied military command rationed food and goods, enforced price and wage regulations, and cigarettes were a real substitute for currency.Soon Ludwig Erhard started to use the phrase to describe his ideas for Germany's post-war economy. And though at the end of the war, Erhard was nearly 50 and had never held any political office what he said mattered, because he became economy minister of West Germany in1949. It was a position he held until 1963.Getting West Germany working again after the war was more important than simply making products or money. Getting people into jobs brought about social peace at a difficult time, and if the country was successful it could fend off communism.Other countries like France, Italy and Austria also experienced a boom, but nothing like Germany, and these years have broadly come to be described as a time of miracles. Erhard for his part has been nicknamed the "father of the German economic miracle" and often called the "incarnation of prosperity" or simply the "miracle man."Erhard's sense of fairness"The outstanding economic development of Germany after the Second World War has been significantly influenced by the social market economy," Jörg Rocholl, president of the European School of Management and Technology (ESMT) in Berlin, told DW. "Its biggest merit is the balance between work and capital in enabling competition. On the one hand, it gives companies the greatest possible freedom. It uses social elements to ensure that those who cannot successfully participate in the economy are socially secure."In the past 70 years the workings of Germany's social market economy have widened and now encompass more than Erhard imagined. His ideas were something between the extremes of ultraliberal laissez-faire economics and a Marxist socialist — in other words a planned — system. Performance-based competition was the key to it all.Basically he wanted a minimally regulated free market economy without day-to-day government interference where supply and demand determined prices, wages and what was produced. He called for private property rights, tough antitrust laws and codetermination, a system that puts worker representatives on company boards in the hope of reaching a consensus on wages, benefits and working conditions.Perhaps what Erhard wouldn't recognize today is the country's welfare system. He loved entrepreneurship and always put the "market" before the "social" in his social market economy and was not in favor of excessive social benefits. He wanted people to work hard and stand on their own as much as possible. Today's current health care, pension and unemployment systems go beyond his ideals. A new world orderJörg Rocholl from ESMT notes that the principles of the social market economy are slowly being softened. He criticizes the government for increasingly intervening in pricing and market mechanisms. A perfect example of this is the current discussion around putting a temporary hold on housing rent hikes in Germany. Not only that, but authorities want to set price limits in the future to cushion rising rents."Any artificial slowing down of the price mechanism like we saw in East Germany leads to a decline in investment and the building infrastructure suffers. In the end, nobody benefits," said Rocholl. Especially this year when Germans are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and the subsequent unification of East and West Germany, many people in the former East feel that they have been left behind. It's not hard to imagine how surprised people in East Germany felt when a new economic and social system was imposed on them in 1989. After all, they had lived in a planned socialist system for many decades and have struggled to catch up.The situation in Eastern Germany is not due to the fact that a market economy is bad, but rather that the East German system was economically finished even before 1989," explained Rocholl, referring to secret internal government reports. "Even before the fall of the Berlin Wall in October 1989, Gerhard Schürer, head of the Central Planning Commission of East Germany, had submitted a secret report on the economic situation of the county to the politburo," according to Rocholl. "The report showed the catastrophic state of the production facilities because of worn-out equipment and an enormous need for repairs. In addition, it showed that the country was already so heavily indebted abroad that a state bankruptcy was imminent."Looking forwardDespite the challenges of integrating East and West in the past three decades, as a whole the unified Germany has roared ahead economically. Today many countries look at its current success to see what parts they can take from it.Erhard called for "prosperity for all" and indeed Germany is riding high at the moment despite a slight recent downturn. When things go well, people don't ask questions. From 2005 to 2019, unemployment dropped from 10% to 5%. But the moment things turn sour, the tides will turn on whatever system is in place.A recent report on Germany's social market economy published by KfW, the country's state owned development bank, point out problems facing the county like growing income disparity, poverty, climate change, a stumbling global trade regime, demographic change and dismal progress in digitalization.This is a long list. Additionally, many businesses say they need more flexibility, especially when it comes to hiring and firing workers. No one system can be everything to everyone, yet it seems like the social market economy is being attached on all sides. Should the economy tank as some are predicting, the cries for it to be dismantled will only grow.Germany must rise to these enormous challenges. The KfW report hit the nail on the head when it stated "securing prosperity is a permanent task." The government will be called on to bring about more social peace and solutions to some big problems. "In his book 'Prosperity for All,' Erhard wrote that as economy minister, he was not the representative of large commercial enterprises and cartels, but someone who had to promote the well-being of everyone by ensuring competition. Exactly this point is more important today than ever. How do we deal with big, powerful companies like the big tech giants? What kind of competition regulation do we need?" concluded ESMT's Rocholl.To stay on top in a changing world, Germany may need to come up with a new "economic miracle" plan.
